subject: Kingsley unicode font posted
msgSnippet: I have uploaded my unicode version of Kingsley to the Fonts folder. This is still a work in progress, but I fear if I keep sitting on it the project will get
messageBody:
I have uploaded my unicode version of Kingsley to the Fonts folder.
This is still a work in progress, but I fear if I keep sitting on it
the project will get buried under other (paying) work that I am doing.
Notably, while the font works on both Mac OS and Windows (hopefully
Linux too), the kerning does not seem to work on Windows 2000. Can
someone using XP tell me how it looks? You might want to try a few
programs, because comments on the FontForge list indicate that the
kerning will work in some (Adobe) programs and not others (Microsoft).

In order to actually see characters in the font, you will need to
either enter them yourself (not easy, since they are all Unicode
points), or use one of the keylayouts I uploaded (Mac only), or
download the "QS_unicode_sample.txt" file that I have also uploaded.

Since I generated this copy of the .ttf, I have changed a few other
things about the font, namely normalizing the character spacing. This
in turn screwed up all the kerning that I had worked to fix, and I
haven't gone through the process of re-fixing it, so this version is
the most publicly-consumable at the moment.

I do, however, have the FontForge .sfd file, if someone is interested
in playing with that. Indeed, I would love to have some more pairs of
eyes looking at it: I can not quite figure out how to encode glyph
alternates: I don't know create glyphs that are not encoded at
specific Unicode points, nor can I get named classes of characters
working. In fact, FontForge crashes on me if I try to create named
classes: this happens on Mac OS X and Windows (under cygwin), and it
happens with other fonts as well, so it is not a Kingsley problem. I
believe the alternate characters can be defined using the 'subs' 'alt
subs' and 'mult subs' sections under the Glyph Info dialog; and thence
I think the when-to-use-which-alternate-characters decision is made in
the 'contextual' section under Font Info... but I haven't really
figured it all out yet. The FontForge documentation is terse.
Trying to create new substitutions is also crashing for me.

oliver
